HJB (HTTP JMS Bridge) links the HTTP protocol to the JMS API.

See:
          Description

Packages
hjb.http Contains the HJBServlet class and support classes.
hjb.http.cmd Provides the interfaces and classes used to process HttpServletRequests and send HttpServletResponses by generating JMSCommands, and sending appropriate responses back the HTTP user agent.
hjb.jms Provides the classes used to register, create and access the JMS objects present in the HJB runtime.
hjb.jms.cmd Provides the interface and classes used to encapsulate the dispatch of invocation of various JMS API methods on the JMS objects contained by HJB.
hjb.misc Contains miscellaneous classes used throughout the various hjb subpackages.
hjb.msg Provides the interface and classes used to allow data to be transferred between HJBMessage and Message instances.
hjb.msg.codec Provides the classes and interface needed to allow values of various Java types encountered in JMS messages to be encoded into and decoded from strings that are suitable for inclusion in either the body or headers of a HTTP message.
hjb.msg.valuecopiers Provides the interface and classes needed to allow values to be read and written from the properties of JMS messages.
hjb.msg.valuecopiers.mapmessage Provides the classes used to allow values read and written from the fields of JMS MapMessages.
hjb.msg.valuecopiers.streammessage Provides the classes used to allow values read and written from the fields of JMS StreamMessages.

 

HJB (HTTP JMS Bridge) links the HTTP protocol to the JMS API.

HJB
  • Provides a RESTful equivalent or the JMS API, i.e, it becomes possible to perform JMS operations by accessing resources via HTTP
  • Covers most of the non-optional parts of the JMS API
  • Provides encoding/decoding of all JMS message types to a textual form suitable for transmission as text in a HTTP message, including the JMS header and property values
  • Is JMS Vendor agnostic - it should work with any JMS-compliant messaging product
  • Is Free Software
